metadata.title: The GroEL–GroES Chaperonin Machine: A Nano-Cage for Protein Folding

sections.text:
Trends The group I chaperonin GroEL and its cofactor GroES are essential components of the cellular machinery of protein folding in bacteria. Homologous chaperonins occur in mitochondria and chloroplast, while more distantly related group II chaperonins are found in archaea and the eukaryotic cytosol.
GroEL is a double-ring complex with ATPase activity that binds non-native SP in the ring opening. Binding of the lid-shaped GroES to GroEL results in

sections.heading: Protein Folding
sections.text:
Manajit Hayer-Hartl,* Andreas Bracher, and F. Ulrich Hartl
The bacterial chaperonin GroEL and its cofactor GroES constitute the paradigmatic molecular machine of protein folding. GroEL is a large double-ring cylinder with ATPase activity that binds non-native substrate protein (SP) via hydrophobic residues exposed towards the ring center. Binding of the lidshaped GroES to GroEL displaces the bound protein into an enlarged chamber, allowing folding to occur unimpaired by aggregation. GroES and SP undergo cycles of binding and release, regulated allosterically by the GroEL ATPase. Recent structural and functional studies are providing insights into how the physical environment of the chaperonin cage actively promotes protein folding, in addition to preventing aggregation. Here, we review different models of chaperonin action and discuss issues of current debate.
the displacement of SP into an enclosed nano-cage for folding to occur unimpaired by aggregation.
GroEL, non-native protein, and GroES undergo ATP-regulated binding and release cycles.
Recent advances indicate that the physical environment of the GroEL–GroES cage can accelerate the folding of some SPs. An effect of steric confinement of SP in the cage may contribute to the rate enhancement of folding.
Department of Cellular Biochemistry, Max Planck Institute of Biochemistry, Am Klopferspitz 18, 82152 Martinsried, Germany
*Correspondence: mhartl@biochem.mpg.de (M. Hayer-Hartl)

sections.heading: The Molecular Chaperone Concept
sections.text:
Proteins are involved in essentially all cellular processes. Following their synthesis on ribosomes as linear chains of amino acids, to become functionally active proteins generally must fold to unique 3D structures. Fundamental insight into the protein folding process was provided by Anfinsen's pioneering experiments, which showed that small proteins can refold spontaneously on removal from denaturant [1]. This finding not only demonstrated that the amino acid sequence dictates the native conformation of a protein as the thermodynamically most stable state but it also implied that the amino acid sequence provides all the information required for folding to occur spontaneously without the aid of additional factors. However, it soon became apparent that test tube refoldingworksmostly for small, single domain proteins andoften only in conditions far removed from those encountered in the cell. Larger proteins and proteins with complex fold topologies often fail to reach their functional structure and instead aggregate. Such proteins tend to populate kinetically trapped non-native conformations during folding that expose hydrophobic amino acid residues to the solvent and thus are prone to form nonfunctional aggregates in a concentration-dependent manner [2–4]. In the highly crowded cellular environment, aggregation is exacerbated as a result of excluded volume effects,which increase the effective concentrations ofmacromolecules [5–7]. Indeed, it has become clear over the past 25 years that cells have evolved essential machineries, referred to as molecular chaperones, that assist protein folding primarily by preventing inappropriate interactions between nonnative polypeptides that would otherwise lead to aggregation [8–10]. Several structurally distinct classes of chaperones, including the Hsp70, Hsp90, and the chaperonin (Hsp60) proteins, prevent aggregation by recognizing hydrophobic amino acids exposed by non-native proteins andmediate folding through ATP-regulated cycles of binding and release [10–13]. The discovery and functional analysis of the large cylindrical chaperonin complexes was particularly informative in developing the current view of cellular protein folding as a chaperone-assisted process [14–16].
Trends in Biochemical Sciences, September 2015, Vol xx. No. x http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.tibs.2015.07.009 1 © 2015 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
The chaperonins are essential for protein folding in all domains of life [10]. They stand out among ATP-dependent chaperones in that they form large 800–1000 kDa double-ring complexes with an internal chamber in each ring. Their basic function is to provide a nano-cage for the folding of single protein molecules to occur in isolation, unimpaired by aggregation. The bacterial chaperonin GroEL, with its lid-like cofactor GroES, is the archetypical member of this fascinating class of protein folding machines. GroEL belongs to the chaperonins of group I, which are found in bacteria as well as in mitochondria and chloroplasts, the eukaryotic organelles that descend from bacterial endosymbionts. More distantly related chaperonins of group II occur in the cytosol of archaea and eukaryotic cells (reviewed in [17,18]). Here, we review recent advances in understanding how the GroEL/ES system promotes protein folding that have been obtained from structural and biochemical studies. We discuss different mechanistic models that have been proposed to explain the mounting evidence that the chaperonin actively promotes protein folding beyond its role in preventing aggregation.

sections.heading: Structural Architecture of GroEL and GroES
sections.text:
Early negative-stain electron microscopic (EM) images of GroEL alone, and with bound GroES, followed by detailed structural characterization by crystallography and cryo-EM have provided a solid foundation for understanding the GroEL/ES functional cycle [8,19]. Like all group I chaperonins, GroEL of Escherichia coli is a cylindrical complex of two heptameric rings of 57 kDa subunits. The subunits are composed of three domains formed by discontinuous sequence elements: an equatorial ATP-binding domain (residues 6–133, 409–523), an intermediate hinge domain (residues 134–190, 377–408), and an apical domain (residues 191–376) that binds non-native SP and GroES [19] (Figure 1A). The C-terminal 23 residues (ending with four Gly-Gly-Met repeats; disordered in the crystal structure) protrude from the equatorial domains into each ring cavity, occluding free passage between cavities. The equatorial domains provide all the intra- and inter-ring contacts between subunits and the two rings are stacked back-to-back in a staggered arrangement, with each subunit in one ring contacting two subunits in the opposite ring (Figure 1B). The apical domains form the entrance to the ring cavity and are connected to the equatorial domains via the intermediate domains, which transmit conformational changes triggered by nucleotide binding and hydrolysis [19]. Helices H (residues 233–243) and I (residues 255–267) of the apical domains expose multiple hydrophobic amino acids towards the ring center, forming a circular surface for the binding of a nonnative SP (Figure 1B,C).
GroES, a dome-shaped heptameric ring of 10 kDa subunits, binds to the ends of the GroEL cylinder, forming the cage in which SP is encapsulated for folding. Each GroES subunit exposes a flexible loop sequence of 22 residues (mobile loop) that mediates the interaction with helices H and I of the GroEL apical domains (Figure 1D–F). Complex formation with GroEL is nucleotidedependent and is associated with extensive en bloc domain movements in GroEL: cooperative binding of ATP to the seven subunits of a GroEL ring primes the ring for GroES binding by inducing a 608 upwards and a 908 clockwise turning motion of the apical domains about a pivot point at residues Gly192 and Gly375 in the intermediate domain [19,20] (Figure 1D). The volume of the GroEL–GroES cage (175 000 Å3) is approximately twice that of a GroEL ring in the absence of GroES [21], sufficient to accommodate SPs up to 60 kDa in size. The hydrophobic binding sites for SP are buried in the GroEL–GroES complex and the inner wall of the cage is hydrophilic in nature [21] (Figure 1D–F), providing an environment permissive for folding. The E. coli phage T4 encodes its own version of GroES, gp31, which forms a taller folding chamber that is required for folding of the major T4 capsid protein gp23 ( 56 kDa) [22,23]. It is interesting to note in this context that the group II chaperonins have a built-in lid mechanism that allows the partial encapsulation of large multidomain proteins that cannot be accommodated in the folding cage in their entirety [24] (Box 1).

sections.heading: The GroEL/ES Protein Folding Cycle
sections.text:
The interactions of GroEL with SP, nucleotide, and GroES that underlie chaperonin-assisted protein folding have been investigated extensively, but several aspects of the mechanism remain to be firmly established [10,25–31].
GroEL/ES Cycling in the Absence of Substrate Irrespective of the presence of SP, GroEL and GroES undergo ATP-regulated binding and release (Figure 2A). An intricate network of nested cooperativity controls this reaction cycle: positive cooperativity of ATP binding within GroEL rings, and negative cooperativity between rings [19,32]. As a result, asymmetry between GroEL rings in terms of nucleotide occupancy and GroES binding is a central feature of the GroEL–GroES interaction. In the apo-state, the GroEL subunits are in equilibrium between the T-state (low affinity for ATP) and the R-state (high affinity for ATP) [33]. Cooperative binding of ATP to one ring stabilizes the R-state and induces the movement of the apical domains that facilitate GroES binding (cis-ring) (t1/2 200 ms) [20,34–36]
Trends in Biochemical Sciences, September 2015, Vol xx. No. x 3
(Figure 2A). The opposite ring (trans-ring) has only low affinity for nucleotide and may remain nucleotide-free (T-state) even at physiological ATP concentration ( 3 mM), resulting from negative inter-ring cooperativity. Upon hydrolysis of the seven ATP in the cis-ring to ADP ( 15 s at 25 8C), the cis-ring is conformationally altered so as to reduce negative inter-ring cooperativity. ATP can then bind to the trans-ring and this causes the release of ADP and GroES from the cis-ring. Subsequent GroES binding, forming a new cis-ring, completes the cycle (Figure 2A).
GroEL/ES Cycling in the Presence of Substrate The acceptor state for non-native SP is the nucleotide-free trans-ring of the GroEL–GroES complex (Figure 2B). Each apical domain of the trans-ring exposes a hydrophobic cleft between helices H and I (Figure 1A–C) competent for binding short hydrophobic peptides in an extended or amphiphilic helical conformation. Collapsed folding intermediates similar to the ‘molten globule’ state, exposing such hydrophobic sequences, engage two or more apical domains for efficient binding and retain only little residual structure [34,37–41]. Binding to GroEL may cause a conformational expansion of SP (t1/2 100 ms) as detected by fluorescence resonance

energy transfer (FRET) [34,42] (Figure 2B). The upward and clockwise movement of the apical domains induced by subsequent ATP binding may mediate a further expansion of tightly bound SP segments, while releasing weakly bound segments. The ATP-mediated expansion is transient (t1/2 15 ms) and is closely followed by conformational compaction of the SP (t1/ 2 200 ms) as it is displaced from the apical domains by GroES [34,42] (Figure 2B). This mechanism of segmental SP release is consistent with the observation of an intermediate state during encapsulation in which SP and GroES are simultaneously bound to GroEL [43,44]. Hence, premature dissociation of SP into free solution is efficiently avoided during encapsulation. Note that encapsulation is energetically unfavorable and thus must be driven by conformational changes resulting fromATP binding. Upon complete release into the newly formed cis-ring, SP is free to fold during the time needed to hydrolyze the seven ATP ( 6 s at 25 8C and 2 s at 37 8C,
Trends in Biochemical Sciences, September 2015, Vol xx. No. x 5
as GroEL ATPase activity is stimulated in the presence of SP) [45,46] (Figure 2B). ATP binding to the trans-ring then results in opening of the cis-cavity and release of SP. Not-yet-folded SP will be rapidly recaptured by the same or another GroEL molecule for a renewed folding cycle. Certain proteins too large to be encapsulated may utilize a mechanism of binding and release from the trans-ring of the GroEL–GroES complex, without encapsulation [47].
Sequential versus Simultaneous Action of GroEL Rings In the chaperonin cycle described above, the two GroEL rings function sequentially and the asymmetric GroEL–GroES complex is the folding-active species. However, symmetric GroEL– GroES2 complexes, in which both GroEL rings are capped by GroES, have also been observed in the absence and presence of SP, suggesting that they represent a transient intermediate in the reaction cycle. The functional significance of these symmetric complexes continues to be a subject of debate [31,46,48–56], as recent reports suggested that they become close to 100% populated in the presence of SP [50,52,54,55]. In the proposed mechanism, the two GroEL rings function simultaneously in protein folding, with ATP hydrolysis and hence GroES binding and release occurring in a stochastic manner (Figure 2C). It is assumed that the rate limiting step of the cycle is the dissociation of ADP from the trans-ring. Binding of SP to the trans-ring would accelerate ADP dissociation so as to allow ATP and GroES binding before the cis-ring has hydrolyzed its ATP [54]. How GroES release is uncoupled from ADP dissociation (Figure 2C) remains unclear, given the high affinity of GroES for nucleotide-bound GroEL. Thus, fundamentally different allosteric mechanisms would underlie the chaperonin cycle in the absence and presence of SP. Notably, these studies employed the same calibrated FRET assay to quantify GroEL–GroES2 complexes but arrived at markedly different results dependent on the fluorophore pair used to label GroEL and GroES [50,52,54,55]. A more recent study using a novel fluorescence cross-correlation assay, avoiding fluorescent labeling of GroEL, failed to confirm the reported effect of SPs to induce GroEL–GroES2 complexes [56]. Interestingly, a high excess of permanently unfolded proteins, such as reduced /-lactalbumin, but not several tested foldable SPs, was found to facilitate the formation of symmetric complexes, apparently by reducing the negative allosteric coupling between the GroEL rings. Furthermore, at a physiological concentration ratio of ATP:ADP ( 10:1), symmetric complexes were strongly disfavored [56], consistent with ADP enhancing negative inter-ring coupling [57]. Thus, the asymmetric functional cycle (Figure 2B) is more likely to operate in vivo.
In Vivo Substrates of GroEL GroEL/ES is required for E. coli growth under all conditions [14], indicating the existence of essential proteins that depend on the chaperonin for folding. While GroEL interacts with a wide range of denatured proteins in vitro, only a limited set of 250 proteins was shown to bind stably to GroEL upon translation in vivo, corresponding to 10% of total E. coli cytosolic proteins and including 67 essential proteins [58] (Figure 3A). A wider range of newly synthesized proteins aggregated upon rapid loss of GroEL function in a temperature-sensitive GroEL mutant strain [59]. Most GroEL interactors are 35–60 kDa in size [58], consistent with the volume of the GroEL–GroES cavity. Some larger proteins were also identified and may utilize GroEL for aggregation prevention, but do not undergo global encapsulation for folding [47]. A subset of the GroEL interactors, 80 proteins, was predicted to have an obligate dependence on GroEL/ES, based on their enrichment on GroEL [58] (Figure 3A). GroEL-depletion experiments confirmed the strict GroEL dependence of 50 of these proteins [58,60]. The obligate SPs occupy 80% of the GroEL capacity and typically have complex//b or/+b domain topologies [58]. Proteins with the (b//)8 TIM-barrel fold are strongly enriched [58,60,61] (Figure 3A,B). Such proteins are stabilized by many long-range contacts in their native states and are prone to populate kinetically trapped intermediates as they navigate their complex folding energy landscapes [2]. Obligate GroEL SPs have less than average abundance and can be predicted based on the physicochemical properties of their amino acid sequences [58,61–63] (Figure 3A).

Non-obligate SPs generally utilize upstream chaperones for folding. (B) Structures of some obligate SPs of GroEL: the TIM-barrel proteins dihydrodipicolinate synthase (DapA) (PDB code 1YXD) and methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MetF) (PDB code 1B5T) and the /+b-fold protein S-adenosylmethionine synthase (MetK) (PDB code 1P7L) are shown.
The substrate selectivity of GroEL in vivo can be understood in light of the fact that GroEL/ES acts downstream of other general chaperones, such as trigger factor (TF) and the Hsp70 system (DnaK/DnaJ/GrpE), which are more abundant than ribosomes ( 30 mM cellular concentration) [10]. These chaperones assist the folding of the majority of newly synthesized proteins that can rapidly bury hydrophobic sequences and thus do not depend on the chaperonin cage for folding [64,65]. An additional function of the upstream chaperones is to prevent the aggregation of obligate GroEL SPs until they can partition to the less abundant GroEL ( 3 mM oligomer) [64]. Indeed, in the absence of TF and the Hsp70 system, a number of additional proteins interact with GroEL. This results in the aggregation of several obligate SPs, indicating that GroEL is overwhelmed and substrate selectivity is lost [58]. Computational modeling is now being applied to generate experimentally testable hypotheses about the flux of proteins through the E. coli chaperone systems [66,67].
GroEL–GroES: More Than an Infinite Dilution Box? The exact mechanism by which the chaperonin system assists in protein folding is still a matter of debate. Three models have been proposed, which differ in whether GroEL/ES solely acts passively by preventing aggregation (passive cage) or additionally promotes the folding process by an active mechanism (active cage and iterative annealing) [30] (Figure 4).

Figure 4. Models of GroEL/ES-Assisted Protein Folding. (Top) Schematic representation of folding and assembly of newly synthesized polypeptides. GroEL substrate proteins (SPs) accumulate as kinetically trapped folding intermediates that are prevented from aggregating by chaperones acting upstream to GroEL. Described in the box are three models that differ in whether GroEL/ES functions only in preventing aggregation during folding (passive cage model) or additionally promotes folding by an active mechanism (active cage and iterative annealing models). The rate of spontaneous folding and GroEL/ES-assisted folding are denoted as kfold-spont and kfold-ELES, respectively. Assembly of GroEL SPs is generally thought to occur spontaneously after subunit folding but may be assisted by specific assembly chaperones in some cases [107].
Passive Cage Model The passive cage model is also referred to as the ‘Anfinsen cage’model to denote the idea that proteins fold inside the GroEL/ES cavity with the same kinetics as they would fold in free solution at infinite dilution, that is, in the absence of aggregation [68] (Figure 4). Although compelling evidence has been presented that obligate SPs must fold inside the cage to avoid aggregation [68,69], the passive cage model conflicts with a large body of evidence that GroEL/ES accelerates the folding of various proteins over their spontaneous folding rate [42,45,69–77], even when spontaneous folding occurs with a very high yield [45,69–72,76]. The proponents of the passive cage model rationalize these findings by suggesting that GroEL/ES prevents reversible protein aggregation that would otherwise slow the spontaneous folding reaction [68,78,79]. However, evidence for the existence of such reversible aggregates is lacking, given that the aggregates observed by light scattering persisted during folding [30,78,79]. This finding is consistent with reports that aggregation of GroEL SPs is an irreversible process that only reduces the yield but does not slow the rate of spontaneous folding [69,70,72,76]. Moreover, recent experiments using single molecule spectroscopy to formally test the passive cage model demonstrated accelerated folding by GroEL/ES under conditions where aggregation during spontaneous folding was excluded [45,76].
Active Cage Model The active cage model (Figure 4) attributes the rate enhancement of folding to an effect of steric confinement of kinetically trapped folding intermediates that are structurally dynamic and thus entropically stabilized [45,69,70,72,76,80]. Such intermediates are generated through

indiscriminate hydrophobic collapse of larger protein domains that contain many long-range interactions in the native state [2,81]. Proteins with a structural knot, which is an unusual chain topology, may also benefit from confinement during folding, based on evidence that GroEL/ES can speed up the knotting process [74,82]. Three features of the cis-cavity have been shown to be crucial in accelerating folding: the volume of the cage relative to the size of SP [70] (Figure 5A); the highly charged cavity wall with a net charge of 42 (189 negatively and 147 positively charged amino acid residues) [45,70–72] (Figure 5B); and the flexible C-terminal Gly-Gly-Met repeat sequences that extend from the equatorial domains into the central cavity [70,77] (Figure 5A).
Theory predicts that entropic confinement of non-native protein in a repulsive (charged) cage can accelerate folding by one to two orders of magnitude. It does this by restricting the conformational freedom of dynamic folding intermediates and rendering the formation of local and longrange contacts, including those present in the folding transition state, more favorable [83–85]. This mechanism would effectively smoothen the folding energy landscape (Figure 6). Indeed, a rate acceleration of 10-fold over the spontaneous folding rate was reported for the model substrate double mutant of maltose-binding protein (DM-MBP) [70,72] and up to 100–fold (at 37 8C in single molecule measurements) for the obligate in vivo substrate dihydrodipicolinate synthase (DapA), a TIM-barrel protein [76] (Figure 3B). In the case of DapA, hydrogen–deuterium exchange coupled to mass spectroscopy showed that the slow spontaneous folding involves the highly cooperative conversion of the TIM-barrel domain from a dynamic, essentially unprotected folding intermediate to the native state. Figure 6. Mechanisms of Accelerated Folding. Simple energy funnel diagrams are shown for a protein populating a kinetically trapped intermediate(s) during spontaneous folding that converts slowly to the native state, resulting from a high energy barrier to folding (left). For the GroEL substrate proteins (SPs) that have been characterized, this energy barrier has a high entropic component and no significant population of fast folding molecules (dotted arrow) was observed to bypass the kinetically trapped intermediate [69,70,72,76]. Confinement in the hydrophilic environment of the GroEL/ES cage (middle) is suggested to result in smoothing of the energy landscape, such that accumulation of an entropically stabilized intermediate is avoided. In the iterative annealing model (right), the kinetically trapped folding intermediate is thought to be actively unfolded by GroEL, followed by repartitioning between fast folding to the native state and reformation of the kinetically trapped intermediate. This mechanism would be effective in accelerating folding only if the trapped intermediate is enthalpically stabilized by non-native interactions and a significant fraction of molecules partitions to a fast trajectory.
as a result of a high entropic energy barrier (Figure 6). By contrast, folding in the chaperonin ciscavity followed a segmental folding regime of the TIM-barrel domain, thereby lowering the entropic component of the folding energy barrier [76]. This is consistent with the finding that engineered intramolecular disulfide bonds can mimic the confinement effect of the GroEL/ES cage by entropically destabilizing dynamic folding intermediates [72]. Direct evidence for reduced chain mobility during folding inside the GroEL/ES cage compared with spontaneous folding was provided by the technique of photoinduced electron transfer coupled to fluorescence correlation spectroscopy (PET-FCS) [45]. Note that certain GroEL SPs, such as mitochondrial rhodanese, do not experience rate acceleration of folding by GroEL/ES [69,86]. The folding intermediate of rhodanese, an 30-kDa protein, may be too small to benefit from confinement [70].
The conserved negatively charged residues of the cavity wall are required for accelerated folding of some SPs [70,72]. It has been proposed that a highly charged cavity would enhance hydrophobic compaction of folding intermediates through an ordering effect on water structure [87]. Indeed, PET-FCS showed increased chain entropy of encapsulated protein when the netnegative charge of the cis-cavity was removed [45]. Although initial measurements of water dynamics inside the cis-cavity using a spin label on GroES did not detect confined water [88], such measurements should also be performed using different probe positions on the cavity wall and in the presence of SP. Interestingly, the cavity wall of the group II chaperonin TRiC displays an asymmetric distribution of surface charge (Box 1).
The C-terminal Gly-Gly-Met repeat sequences are also required for accelerated folding [70,77]. They may provide a flexible, mildly hydrophobic interaction surface that facilitates SP remodeling, consistent with molecular dynamics simulations suggesting that a moderately hydrophobic cavity could accelerate folding [89]. In addition, these unstructured sequences may exert entropic excluded volume effects to enhance SP compaction [90,91]. It has also been reported that the C-terminal tails contribute to capturing non-native SP for efficient encapsulation [43,92,93].
Iterative Annealing Model The iterative annealing model (Figure 4) proposes an alternative explanation for accelerated folding. In this model, the ATP-driven cycles of SP binding and release from GroEL accelerate
10 Trends in Biochemical Sciences, September 2015, Vol xx. No. x
folding by periodically unfolding misfolded states that are kinetically stabilized by non-native contacts (i.e., enthalpic rather than entropic stabilization), affording them a chance to partition between rapid productive folding and reformation of the kinetically trapped state [25] (Figure 6). In this model, folding may occur either inside or outside the chaperonin cage, thus negating the functional significance of the cage in providing an aggregation-free folding environment [54,55,94]. While a conformational expansion of SP upon binding to GroEL and ATP-induced apical domain movements has been observed [34,35,42], it remains unclear whether these conformational changes are required for subsequent accelerated folding. Importantly, in all cases where enhancement of folding kinetics by chaperonin was observed, the effect was reproduced upon a single step of SP binding to GroEL, followed by stable encapsulation with GroES [45,69,70,72,76,77] (Figure 4). These experiments took advantage of a single ringmutant of GroEL that binds SP, ATP, and GroES but does not release GroES as a result of the absence of the negative allosteric signal from the trans-ring [28,32]. Thus, iterative annealing cycles of SP binding and release are not required for accelerated folding, but annealing would have to occur in a single step of productive remodeling. Furthermore, several studies indicate that folding must occur inside the cage to achieve rate acceleration [69–71], consistent with recent kinetic evidence that SP spends at least 80% of the duration of the GroEL/ES cycle in the encapsulated state and less than 5% in free solution [45]. Theoretical modeling also indicates that folding yield declines as a result of aggregation the more time the SP spends outside the cage [30]. The extent to which the conformational expansion of SP observed upon GroEL binding contributes to subsequent folding warrants further investigation.

sections.heading: Role of Chaperonin in Evolution
sections.text:
Protein evolution is based on the Darwinian selection of mutant proteins. However, most mutations either structurally destabilize the native state of a protein or result in the formation of kinetically trapped folding intermediates [95,96]. It has been suggested that GroEL/ES facilitates the structural evolution of proteins by buffering deleterious effects of mutations on foldability and stability [70,97–102]. For example, overexpression of GroEL/ES allowed previously chaperonin-independent monomeric proteins to accumulate an increasing number of destabilizing mutations [97,101]. A similar effect of GroEL/ES, although less pronounced, was observed in recent studies on the evolvability of the abundant enzyme ribulose bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase (Rubisco) [103,104]. The limited buffering effect in this case was attributed to the fact that the wild-type large subunit of Rubisco is already GroEL/ES-dependent for folding [105], consistent with the notion that adaptation to obligatory chaperone dependence may slow evolvability [99]. Indeed, a bioinformatic survey revealed slower evolutionary rates for GroEL-interacting proteins than for noninteractors [63]. By contrast, some GroEL-dependent metabolic enzymes were found to have a relatively recent evolutionary history, and this was interpreted in support of the view that chaperonins accelerate evolution [106]. These results are consistent with the possibility that some proteins utilize GroEL only for a limited period during their evolution. Once a mutant protein has been selected based on favorable functional properties, secondary mutations may improve its folding efficiency and solubility, allowing the protein to become less GroEL-dependent. Thus, the extant GroEL substrates are proteins that have either failed to acquire such secondary mutations or, being of low abundance, have not experienced the evolutionary pressure to do so.
Escape from chaperonin dependence during evolution is exemplified by the existence of orthologs of obligate GroEL SPs in a small number of bacteria that have no GroEL/ES [76,102]. Notably, the TIM-barrel protein N-acetylneuraminic acid aldolase (NanA) of E. coli is GroEL-dependent in vivo and in vitro [58,60], but its ortholog in Mycoplasma synoviae (Ms), which lacks GroEL/ES, folds rapidly and spontaneously in vitro [76]. The hydrophobic core of MsNanA is enriched in aromatic residues and several/-helices of the TIM-barrel domain contain multiple lysines on their solvent exposed surfaces, conferring high helical propensity. Outstanding Questions Does the GroEL–GroES chaperonin system act purely as a passive folding cage or does it actively promote the folding process for some SPs? An active mechanism may be necessary if spontaneous folding is too slow, resulting in premature degradation.
What are the mechanisms underlying the observed rate acceleration of SP folding by chaperonin? Two models have been proposed, active cage and iterative unfolding/annealing, which are not mutually exclusive and may act in synergy.
Does folding inside the nano-cage alter the folding pathway of SP compared with folding that occurs in solution? Obligate in vivo SPs of GroEL should be analyzed to address this question.
Why are certain proteins highly chaperonin-dependent, while others with similar native structure are not? How do the spontaneous folding pathways of these proteins differ?
How does the group II chaperonin TRiC promote folding and why is GroEL–GroES unable to mediate the folding of obligate TRiC SPs?

ATP and GroES binding trigger conformational changes that result in the release of SP into a cage-like compartment for folding to proceed in isolation. During the time needed for ATP hydrolysis, the encapsulated protein can attempt to fold to the native state. Finally, binding of ATP and GroES to the opposite ring opens the cage and allows SP release (modified from [110]). The extent to which the chaperonin nano-cage actively promotes the folding process is a focus of ongoing investigation. The structural model is based on PDB accession 1AON.

sections.heading: Concluding Remarks
sections.text:
The GroEL/ES chaperonin system has been widely studied as a paradigm macromolecular machine for more than 25 years. It has been a source of inspiration and controversy to the present day. There is (almost) general agreement that the most significant feature of the chaperonin is to provide a compartment in which a single protein molecule is transiently enclosed and allowed to fold in isolation, thereby avoiding aberrant interactions that would otherwise lead to aggregation (Figure 7, Key Figure). Whether this compartment acts purely as a passive folding cage or actively promotes the folding process for some proteins is a matter of ongoing investigation. While there is ample evidence that the GroEL/ES system can accelerate the rate of protein folding, the underlying mechanisms are not yet well understood. It is the view of the authors that the confining environment of the cage is crucial in converting kinetically trapped folding intermediates to the native state. In any case, the resulting rate enhancement of the folding process is biologically relevant to ensure that proteins reach their functionally active state at the timescale of synthesis. Based on recent evidence, chaperonin dependence correlates with sequence properties that favor indiscriminate hydrophobic collapse, resulting in the formation of dynamic folding intermediates. Such folding intermediates would be destabilized by entropic confinement. Future experiments using authentic in vivo substrates of GroEL should focus on whether and how the chaperonin modulates the folding pathway compared with spontaneous folding in bulk solution. A related problem is to understand how certain proteins have evolved to be chaperonin-independent while their structural homologs are not. It will be interesting to see what surprises the GroEL/ES machine may still have in store (see Outstanding Questions).
12 Trends in Biochemical Sciences, September 2015, Vol xx. No. x

The subunits are composed of three domains formed by discontinuous sequence elements: an equatorial ATP-binding domain (residues 6–133, 409–523), an intermediate hinge domain (residues 134–190, 377–408), and an apical domain (residues 191–376) that binds non-native SP and GroES [19] (Figure 1A).

The apical domains form the entrance to the ring cavity and are connected to the equatorial domains via the intermediate domains, which transmit conformational changes triggered by nucleotide binding and hydrolysis [19].

Complex formation with GroEL is nucleotidedependent and is associated with extensive en bloc domain movements in GroEL: cooperative binding of ATP to the seven subunits of a GroEL ring primes the ring for GroES binding by inducing a 608 upwards and a 908 clockwise turning motion of the apical domains about a pivot point at residues Gly192 and Gly375 in the intermediate domain [19,20] (Figure 1D).

The substrate selectivity of GroEL in vivo can be understood in light of the fact that GroEL/ES acts downstream of other general chaperones, such as trigger factor (TF) and the Hsp70 system (DnaK/DnaJ/GrpE), which are more abundant than ribosomes ( 30 mM cellular concentration) [10].
These chaperones assist the folding of the majority of newly synthesized proteins that can rapidly bury hydrophobic sequences and thus do not depend on the chaperonin cage for folding [64,65].

An additional function of the upstream chaperones is to prevent the aggregation of obligate GroEL SPs until they can partition to the less abundant GroEL ( 3 mM oligomer) [64].
This results in the aggregation of several obligate SPs, indicating that GroEL is overwhelmed and substrate selectivity is lost [58].

Three models have been proposed, which differ in whether GroEL/ES solely acts passively by preventing aggregation (passive cage) or additionally promotes the folding process by an active mechanism (active cage and iterative annealing) [30] (Figure 4).
Assembly of GroEL SPs is generally thought to occur spontaneously after subunit folding but may be assisted by specific assembly chaperones in some cases [107].

Passive Cage Model The passive cage model is also referred to as the ‘Anfinsen cage’model to denote the idea that proteins fold inside the GroEL/ES cavity with the same kinetics as they would fold in free solution at infinite dilution, that is, in the absence of aggregation [68] (Figure 4).

Although compelling evidence has been presented that obligate SPs must fold inside the cage to avoid aggregation [68,69], the passive cage model conflicts with a large body of evidence that GroEL/ES accelerates the folding of various proteins over their spontaneous folding rate [42,45,69–77], even when spontaneous folding occurs with a very high yield [45,69–72,76].

Although compelling evidence has been presented that obligate SPs must fold inside the cage to avoid aggregation [68,69], the passive cage model conflicts with a large body of evidence that GroEL/ES accelerates the folding of various proteins over their spontaneous folding rate [42,45,69–77], even when spontaneous folding occurs with a very high yield [45,69–72,76].

The proponents of the passive cage model rationalize these findings by suggesting that GroEL/ES prevents reversible protein aggregation that would otherwise slow the spontaneous folding reaction [68,78,79].

metadata.abstractText: The bacterial chaperonin GroEL and its cofactor GroES constitute the paradigmatic molecular machine of protein folding. GroEL is a large double-ring cylinder with ATPase activity that binds non-native substrate protein (SP) via hydrophobic residues exposed towards the ring center. Binding of the lidshaped GroES to GroEL displaces the bound protein into an enlarged chamber, allowing folding to occur unimpaired by aggregation. GroES and SP undergo cycles of binding and release, regulated allosterically by the GroEL ATPase. Recent structural and functional studies are providing insights into how the physical environment of the chaperonin cage actively promotes protein folding, in addition to preventing aggregation. Here, we review different models of chaperonin action and discuss issues of current debate. the displacement of SP into an enclosed nano-cage for folding to occur unimpaired by aggregation.
